posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26332619
>Creating an EV needs 2X the energy and more materials than an ICE car.
Depends greatly on what EV we're talking about. But even looking at EVs from a decade ago when they almost all were all higher end heavier cars, the energy and emissions differences from production were paid back in the much lower emissions from operation relatively quickly.
This trend has accelerated as EVs have switched to using batteries made from more common materials, and ICE vehicles have gotten heavier.
The real main factor in how much materials a vehicle uses now, is really just when it was last refreshed and what year's safety requirements it has to conform to.
EVs have a bit of an advantage in safety requirements since the MR Layout most of them use is fundamentally safer than a front engine which can get pushed into the passenger compartment.

>When running, most of the electricity consumed by an EV comes from fossil fuels.
Depends greatly on where you live. In modern first-world countries, fossil fuels make up a pretty small percentage of the grid's baseload capacity. The US for instance already gets as much of its power from clean nuclear energy as it does from coal, and new nuclear plants have finally started to be approved.
Of course even in the worst case scenario where its run entirely on coal a 4 mile a kWh electric car will still come out ahead of a gas car on emissions.
The fact hardly anywhere is totally reliant on coal anymore just means EVs are that much cleaner.

>When recycling the cars, EVs are in whole different league due to batteries' difficulty.
While its true batteries aren't getting recycled, that's more to do with the fact that EV batteries last longer than anyone expected them to a decade ago, and re-use of old packs is far more common.
When they are finally done being used, batteries are very recyclable, and there is no negative effects on batteries from using lithium or other elements that were used in batteries before.

>>26330327
One last time, and I'm going to call it a day, since I'm only doing this to show the rest here how thick you are.

1. Manufacturers sell to dealerships who in turn have to pay a loan on the vehicle to the manufacturer in the time it sits on its lot.

Therefore manufacturer makes money both on the sale of the vehicle to the dealership + the interest paid by the dealership to the manufacturer, and has the additional bonus of the manufacturer dealing with a couple of hundred dealerships vs hundreds of thousands of people.

Getting rid of this means the manufacturer loses money, as they lose the interest paid and now have to pay for customer service + service centers (See #3)

2. Selling to dealerships means that there's a buffer in sales if there's an economic down turn. If the economy goes tits up, Ford or Honda doesn't have to layoff their employees, paying them either severance (as most of these operations are unionized) or their unemployment insurance gets jacked up. Either way the company has to pay out through the nose for little or no production if they shut down. If they can keep sending units to their dealerships they avoid this.

Which also refutes your dumb idea that it would facilitate more sales to customers, If the economy goes tits up, then the manufacturers would make LESS sales than with the dealership network in place.

3. Service centers cost money to operate, and having dealerships burden the cost, whilst charging them access to the manufacturers parts network Means they don't have to pay for brick and mortar overhead (which if you had one iota of business knowledge you'd know is fucking expensive) and employing services techs and again still making money off of OEM parts sales.

4. And most importantly CORPORATIONS DO NO GIVE A SHIT ABOUT YOU. I've explained multiple times that manufacturers make more money off this with dealership in place since if a dealership fucks you over, their hands are clean of the mess.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26324533
The energy of density of hydrogen is actually great, better even than gasoline. The problem is the volumetric density means you need pressure vessels to store it, and getting power out of the hydrogen compared to batteries is about 1/2 as efficient with fuel cells, and 1/4 as efficient with internal combustion.

So where a 400 mile range EV only needs a ~500kg 100kWh battery that can fit entirely under the floor, doing the same thing with an FCEV requires about 180kWh of hydrogen, which while its only 5.6kg of hydrogen requires significant bulk in the storage tanks and the fuel cell stack consuming the entire front of the vehicle, the whole 'transmission tunnel' as well as the 'fuel tank' area.
All of which can be done, but nobody really wants to spend the money for 5.6kg of hydrogen when its $15 a kg. Especially when fast charging is cheaper, and really doesn't take that much longer once you consider you're not stuck by the car monitoring the refueling.

Hydrogen ICE is simply never going to happen outside of race cars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26333283
Use JIS or good fitting screwdrivers. Think of each screw that it's going to strip on you, so I like to lean over a table, put weight on the carbs and pop the screw free with a ton of downward force.
Or use a vice+wrench on the flats on the handle or stem of the screwdriver.

Oh, and I do mine over white towels, and prefer to take them apart one at a time and clean them. I use stranded copper wire/electrical wire to poke through stubborn parts, and I look through the jet at a light to make sure it's clean.

Have fun.

posts.sub: Why aren’t there any hybrid electric/turboshaft cars?
posts.com: It seems like the perfect combination. Electric for the low end, and the turboshaft kicks on at the high end.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26330185
Because the economics for companies making hybrids is in the favor of re-using as much of their existing piston engine investments as possible while they dip their toes in the developing electric side of the industry. Their expectation is that they'll be full-electric someday, so they don't see the point in investing new new range-extender technology.
Meanwhile for the battery electric car makers their primary economic benefit comes from lowering the cost of their batteries and the packaging makes it easy to pack in 80 or 100kWh of batteries to reach 300 or 400 miles of range. They're projecting that continues, as does the ability of their batteries to take charge more quickly when fast charging. They're not really interested in range-extenders at all.

So there isn't anybody in the market who is going to make the investment to make a new turbine car. Nor is there any class in motorsports that would encourage investment in the idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26330185
You’d be better off using the turbine to power a generator to keep it operating at peak efficiency. Connecting it directly to the drivetrain sounds like more trouble than it’s worth if you’ve already got electric motors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26330185
turbines aren't efficient until really high speeds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26330356
That's only an issue if the turbine has a fixed physical connection to the wheels. With a Turbine PHEV there would likely either be no physical connection at all, like the BMW i3, or a physical connection through a single reduction gear that only gets engaged at speed, like the Chevy Volt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26330185
Chrysler spent decades blowing inordinate sums of money trying to make the turbine engine worth the cost increase over a piston engine and it never worked out. They got it to where it could match a piston engine in power and fuel economy, but had a premium of $10k 1960s money over a standard V8 (about the cost of buying two Corvettes new on top of the rest of the car's purchase price). Then the 70s happened and while they tried, they never got it to pass new emissions requirements, so the program died unceremoniously with a whimper in the 80s and here we are.

> looks like the future
maybe if you're an African bushman speaking in clicks
most people associate iPads with 5 year olds playing candy crush

more philosophically, people respect tools entirely, wholly devoted to their task - unity of purpose. A screen, by contrast, multi tasks.
Interrelated with unity of purpose, is separation of church and state -> separating things creates order, contrast, and harmony, mixing them up in an amorphous screen is hell (metaphorically speaking). Under this principle, not only do you want your tools with unified each with their own purpose, you want them physically delineated and separated. On the car tablet, there is no such separation, as every element is still part of the same glass screen.
Another aesthetic value is restraint - not using more effort than you need to. if you are using pixels, screens and electricity for something that can be done just as well, and even more delightfully, with a simple hardware stick, you are overdoing it, trying too hard.
A final principle of aesthetics is authenticity, genuineness. By its very nature a screen constantly shifts and moves, it's an illusion, a lie. You may like seeing skilled illusionists at a circus once a month but you don't want your life becoming a circus

tldr screen lovers are trannies or misguided tech-idolaters

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Friends, I'm trying to compile as much advice as possible about preserving a car through NE winters without a garage. I know it's not ideal but it's just the way it is for me right now. So far I've got:

> properly fitted cover
> treating the undercarriage as often as practical
> avoid driving in winter period or at least for a few weeks after last road salting
> give praise to God every day
> drop some oxygen absorbers inside the car and under the cover

what else can I do? do you suppose a thermal layer beneath the cover like a big space blanket would help regulate temperature? what's the best animal to sacrifice on my hood and how often?

posts.name: 61 lincoln guy
posts.com:
>>26331752
the desiccant packs are a really good idea

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26331752
>few weeks after last road salting
You need at minimum a few heavy downpours to wash most of the salt away. It's not necessarily time dependant. You just need to be patient enough to wait until then.
>Covers
Covers can do more harm than good a lot of times, especially if you're in a windy area. All that movement erodes your clearcoat right away. Ask me how I know about that one.
>rodents
You're gonna need to go on a very heavy anti rodent campaign around your whole property; inside and outside. Never let up, never get lazy or they will find a way into your car.
>chock blocks
Use them. Or a brick. Do not use your parking brake.
>Check ups
Check on the car fairly often to make sure water or rodents aren't getting in.
Remove the battery and put it in your basement.
Resist the temptation to "start the engine every once in awhile". For your last drive of the season, just put STABIL in after filling the gas, run for like a couple minutes to get the STABIL circulated and then just keep it off until spring when the salt is all gone.
Oh and throw a drip pan under the engine and transmission so you can tell if those have any slow leaks.
There's probably more but that's all I can think of for now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26331752
Are you just storing it in your driveway or are you gonna be driving it? And what's the condition of the car? Does it leak when it rains?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26331752
If you're storing it for winter and not a super long time (like 1yr+) don't worry about chock blocks or putting it on stands.
>Cover
Unless you've got a soft top or something that leaks like crazy any time it rains, don't bother with one.
>Salty roads
Just don't drive on it until you've had a few good rains. If you happen to do so, I suggest getting something that you can use to spray hot water under your car to wash it.
>Rates/mice
I just put a couple of packs of moth balls inside the car and engine bay and never had issues with them
>Occasional start up
Fill it with premium and if you start it up, let it run for 20 or so mins. Never start it for a min or so, does more harm than good

>>26326126
When was the last time you changed your ATF?
If never and the fluid is dark, change it with dextron 6 and a new filter and do a 3x3 flush with it (3 flushes 3 times with 3 new filters)
if it still happens your plastic pistons inside the transmission have most likely cracked and are leaking past the seals, I was going to get billet aluminum pistons made just before my red SF got totaled.
I managed to save my gold foresters 4eat with a 3x3 flush.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26326542
Do they really spec timing belts for euro cars every 100k km? In the US it's every 150-168k km.
But i'd pop your timing belt inspection cover (3 10mm bolts, left head on SOHC) because they also spec every 7 years so check for cracking or striping of the belt.
Really nothing much needs to be done at the first mileage service aside from the belt and maybe trans if its an auto, normally you can ignore the water pump for the first go around. But absolutely replace the timing cog located right next to it as they're infamous about burning the bearing out and taking out the timing belt.
side note on those cogs, for OE there's a few different part numbers but I've always gone off of what color the bearing was; orange, green and black. I've found that the green ones tend to last longer but that's bordering pseudoscience.
>>26326546
In my neck of the woods that's about average mileage for the 2.5 with memegaskets, at that age it more depends on how it was treated by its owner because it's well outside of the lemon period. The 2.0 isn't known for big problems like the 2.5 was.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26329832
I've never really heard of people having issues with them apart from the timing chain fandangling if you ever need to replace it (special tools and dumb procedure), the 2.3 being quick to start knocking from main bearings going bad after 250k kms or so, and the 3rd gear syncro on the 5 speed being a bit weak.
I've got a first gen 2.0 manual, third will grind if you try and slam it into gear like you're an ape, but if you shift like a human being it's fine, and hasn't gotten worse in my 30k km of ownership (250k total). Every other issue I've had has either been minor maintenance (thermostat stuck open so runs cold, shocks are just starting to feel a little bit tired going over big bumps or really rough surfaces) or caused by retardation (has been involved in several accidents, previous owner had the airbags deployed and a few small scrapes on the bumpers, I hit a kangaroo and reversed into a bin).
It's one of the most well put together cars I've ever driven, and the appearance and mileage belies the surprisingly decent handling (on good 17" tyres) and the mix of comfort and fun factor. If I was told it had 150k I'd believe it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26323776

Audi and Subaru both committed the entire brand to the set up. Subaru uses compact boxer engines to reduce the weight and distribution of that weight. Audi intially wanted a 4 cylinder as well to keep weight down and a 6 cylinder was too much weigh too far forward so they ran 5 cylinders for a very long time. Then they developed very small compact engines to reduce the effect. The current V8 in the RS6 is shorter than the old inline 5 and cast out of aluminum.

They also have innovated the transaxle to allow the engine to sit more rearward than before so the weight distribution is more around 54/44 than the older 61/39.

Audi and Subaru do not get a pass. They get mocked all the time for the Achilles heel. But they’re significantly better than the acura situation which has no means to addrsss the problem, and really no need too since nobody expects an Acura or Honda ti be fun to drive

>fuckin dope. what was it like?
Had it from 2013 to 2022. Honestly it was a great car so long as you kept on top of it. Mine was in kind of rough shape and needed a motor rebuild when I bought it which is did in the first year. After that it was my daily driver until about 2018.

When I was driving it every day it was great. I had weird issues like when I needed to have the computer replaced because the sauder started coming apart.

The Problems didn't really start until I changed jobs and suddenly had a commute that was 30 miles instead of 5 and involved driving on the busiest parts of the freeway and downtown. I bought myself a Saab for $1500 and the 944 turned into my "weekend car"

Then I moved and it had to go into storage and just started to rot from lack of use. I finally let it go to a guy who was working on my mom's house last summer because it was his favorite model of Porsche. I figured it was better going to a good home than rotting away in a storage unit because my apartment wouldn't let me park 2 cars and the office complained about it being "loud"

If you have any intention of getting a 944 do the research that I didn't when I bought mine and wait until you find one of the at least decently kept ones. Otherwise be prepared to sink a grand a year into all the random shit that will break that you will never expect.

>>26332122
that's me, what do you need to know?
there are guides all over the place, but the main thing is access. you HAVE to permanently damage something, but what you actually damage is your choice:
>go through the wiper blade motor / battery area and have to destroy the baffle housing itself
>go through the dash and destroy the vent ducting (route i took, see the huge gashes in the vent and the taped column of plastic held down by painters tape)
in my picture >>26327489 you can see the metal baffle. well, that's one of two baffles. the one you can see if the diverter for vent directionality. the other is just to the left of it and diverts air through the heater core.
you have to do both. i used Gorilla's flex seal competitor tape since it's so wide and kinda soft. i poked little holes all over it to replicate whatever Porsche was thinking by using permeable foam instead of a solid aluminum baffle. maybe the porous nature of the foam keeps the servos from slamming when the baffles fire under fan pressure or something.

>pic for bumping

posts.com:
>>26328562
It's a cute little car but I'd advise against that especially as a first car.
It's over 30 years old and you're looking to daily drive it. Be aware that a whole lot of stuff is going to need replacement. It's up to you to do it immediately or to have a breakdown ever other weak because some rubber piece (or worse) went.
This particular model was never common and has been completely gone for over a decade. If you need any part not shared with a Civic you're utterly screwed, and even if it was shared it may still be a problem.
Despite looking cool, it is a 30yo entry level shitbox. Don't think they drove nice when they were new. Don't think the last 30 years made anything better. They didn't.
You're also looking for your first car. This means that you will hoon it and you will ding it. Or worse. I know it's a thought that hurts but the sad truth is both are true for almost all starters, though people tend to lie about it. Anyways, this makes it all the more likely that you will need e.g. a rear light after backing into a dumpster.

It would make a cool secondary car, but as a beginners only source of mobility it's really asking for trouble.

I'm having a braking problem with my volvo 940 and google is giving me exact same "top 5 symptoms" across every site I look at.

The other night I went for a drive when my brake pedal started getting increasingly hard to push, and the car started slowing down even if I tried to floor it, over the course or about 60 seconds. I pulled up, all four of my rims were very hot to the touch, and the car wouldn't roll even in neutral. I opened the bleeder valve on the master cylinder (into a can) and fluid shot out, and my brakes no longer worked so I limped it home around the corner.

I bled the brakes, and went for a quick spin, and the pedal started going hard again with the car slowing down, I tried a new booster check valve, same problem. So I disconnected the booster vacuum line and put a bolt in it, and now the pedal is obviously had as shit, but the brakes are free.

I can't find and reputable sites stating that a brake booster can cause the brakes to lock, but through my testing it seems to be the case. Brake hoses are newish and I religiously change my fluid. Replacement booster isn't available, so before get my booster (((rebuilt))), does anyone have any insight?

posts.name: Anonymous

It's the booster/servo. Specifically, it sounds like the atmospheric valve is sticking, preventing the "atmosphere" side of the diaphragm from venting when the brake pedal returns, building up positive pressure in that side of the chamber, keeping the brakes applied progressively more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26324956
This period of mb is absolutely full of features like that, but the real magic is in the serviceability. Despite being some of the best built cars of the era, they're really easy to disassemble and fix. The more difficult jobs tend to be ones that don't happen often, like top cylinders or a heater core. As far as features go, I'll list a few
>service position for the hood allowing it to lift to 90 degrees
>front corner lights are a simple press fit
>includes unused pigtails for certain parts allowing seamless plug and play upgrades (like halogen>xenon headlights)
>the airbox/engine cover is a press fit
>the gauge cluster is a press fit and can be removed by removing 3 easy to access screws, dropping the lower half of the dash and simply pushing it out
>the ac and radio are a press fits and can be removed with a hook tool
>the seat bottoms and backs can be removed with 2-3 easy to reach screws, allowing you to access the seat frame and all components
>for the rear lights, all bulbs are mounted to a panel that swings out
>engine harness disconnects inside the engine bay, meaning you don't have to remove it from the engine or pull the dash apart
Of course they're also complicated, and diagnosis can be difficult sometimes. The flip side is owning a car where it feels like the people who designed and built it were thinking of you. That's where the "built to a standard, not a price point" thing comes from

A friend with a low mile S600 had to spend $3,000 having a shop replace rear SLS (hydraulic self-leveling suspension) shocks and spheres. I think S600s have ADS as well (adaptive damping system) which possibly involves hydraulic front shocks too? I can't readily find too much info about it, but I know there is some degree of electronic control as it gives you a button in the cabin to firm up the suspension or something.
You can look up my post for the rear suspension; for a non-ADS car like mine, I'm confident you can solve the rear suspension in a weekend for under $500, that's NOT via converting to conventional shocks.
S600s are also leather wrapped everywhere in the interior, which means interior parts are slightly harder to find. The Transmissions are different and this same friend had to have his serviced for $$$ when it stopped going into reverse.
I can't give any exact maintenance figures beyond that, but FWIW, this guy with a S600 dailies a new AMG G wagen.

>>26320813
I guarantee, the second you flash that ECU there is a digital counter marker called TD1 that will go from being a zero to being one. If you ever need engine repairs under warranty, the first thing any Audi technician is going to do is look for that marker and if they see it they're going to reject your claim. You might get lucky with a third party warranty Where a third party automotive repair shop has an incentive to not disclose performance modifications to the warranty company in order to increase approval odds on a claim, but there is a 100% chance your factory warranty from Audi Will be voided on the engine and probably drive train the second you bring it in for repairs.

TD1 cannot be reset back to zero, flashing the ECU back to stock won't hide it.

JB4 or similar piggyback units might be safer since they don't hit the TD1 marker but if you need serious engine repair Audi will look at sensor logs and if they see evidence of a piggyback unit they will deny your claim.

Keep this in mind.

>>26320854
I have a tuned S6 running bunkers numbers and fully modified suspension and my dealer loves the car and always run my warranty. I’m not a fag to them though, I pay their fees and am friendly with the desks and mechanics.

Not saying I’m special but pointing out that it’s not a guarantee they’ll deny the warranty.

Also, I had an S3 running 400hp for a while (again warrantied through Audi dealer no problem). IMO the A4/S4 is better than the S3/A3. The Quattro system in the A4 (ultra) and the S4 (crown/torsen) is worth paying for.

Quattro ultra has the detached rear axle when you don’t need awd. Audi noticed it’s A4/Q5 customers were thinking in terms of ‘gee AWD uses more gas so maybe I’ll get FWD and stay home if it snows’ instead of thinking about sporty ness. Since torsen uses .6L of fuel extra per 60km Quattro ultra uses .2L and so it offers the best of both worlds for customers that were torn on Quattro. It’s also exoerimxe better than torsen in the snow/ice as ids faster to get torque where it needs to go.
Haldex sucks bad. The engine is all forward of the front axle. It barely sends power rear except in extreme situations and the worst part is it breaks in as little as 10k miles. The A4 ultra is fwd biased like Haldex but the weight is minimal, the engine is mroe rear, the system is much more siphsitaced in terms of engaging the clutch and it’s much more robust and has no issues with reliability.

The nice thing about the A4 is the current 4 cylinder is very reliable and the water pump meme is covered by a recall. I doubt you have warranty issues to worry about. Since Audi puts engines on the front axle a 4 cylinder is ideal because it’s compact and weighs little so the A4 has a good argument for handling the best.
Order an 034 Motorsport rear sway bar and you”ll have a very neutral handling car with great awd and a DCT.

>always engages atleast 1%

>mostly 95/5 or less front wheel drive based
>fragile transfer case breaks often
>fragile pump breaks often

A4 Q5 A5 Q7 quattro ultra
>~65% more Efficient than regular Quattro
>weighs much less
>can be 100% FWD
>uses sensors everywhere can predict wet surfaces or when the multi link suspension will adjust camber and more grip will be needed
>reliable
>has adequate cooling to run much more aggressive use
>fastest response to ice snow and water
>50/50 is max distribution

S and RS Torsen/crown
>coolest
>sportiest
>reliable
> takes time to shift torque

https://youtu.be/IaysomUDgXQ

Like I said Audis Quattro team developed ultra without being told too purely because they found A4 / Q5 customers cared more about efficiency comfort and snow than sportyness and ultra is successful at both being more efficient than torsen and escaping low traction situations.


https://youtu.be/MqFKd-hTWO4

You can also see that ultra is totally superior to Haldex. There are situations where Haldex simply cannot send enough torque where it needs to go to get the vehicle rolling. Note as well that Audi (not VW) does give more power to the rear on Haldex units when traction control is off.

That’s of coruse ignoring the benefits of ultras effiency, reliability, and smooth predictive engagement. It’s just a better system.

And for most A4/Q5 buyers it’s going to be the desired choice.

MLB is a vastly better platform with better Materials. VW only uses it for Touareg

Nigger i work on the shitboxes. They are the most common thing for me to visit ebay for. Land cruiser AC amplifier, land cruiser AC mode door actuator (not at dealer or parts stores), toyota pickup turn signal/wiper combination switch, relay control module internally shorted. None of this shit is available through parts stores, only dealer or ebay. And, like I said, they will charge $400 for a single thermistor. A basic electronic component.
Oh, and chassis wise, they're weak as shit. I'd rather have the strength of a 90s kia sportage. One 4runner with the nice X-REAS suspension was almost totaled because it hit a bump too hard and the hubs bent inward. Wheels aren't bent, control arms aren't bent, tires aren't blown out, but the hubs gave way and one shock blew out. Almost totaled because the parts are too expensive and the guy had to get all of it from a boneyard himself.
I would only have one for the jacked up retard resale price.
Yes, I feel strongly about this opinion.

My point was that it's a 4.5" standard, they didn't make a "114.3" just as a coincidence.

It's because the U.S. rebuilt Japan after WWII. We sent them machinery from GM and Ford. Harley Davidson even sent tooling to make HD's in Japan for the Japanese market.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26308415
I daily my NB and it's great. It's comfortable (stock) and the trunk is adequate for grocery trips. I would not recommend dailying such an old car for people who don't wrench themselves, not sure if you do. I wouldn't want to hand it off to a non-car person like wives tend to be until you've gone through it and replaced old rubber parts like brake hoses, calipers, hard/cracked coolant/vacuum hoses, suspension bushings and joints, etc to minimize failure points that could leave her stranded. Luckily NA/NB is piss easy to work on and all the upgrades you could ever think of are well documented online like at miata.net, if you can think of something you'd want to do to it or had a problem, someone has already tried it out/fixed it and made a forum post about it. The NB is a much better car to live with in every way (and cheaper), but if you're set on an NA for the flippy lights I'd understand. I don't think you'll need any backup camera stuff, the visibility with the top up is pretty good and with the top down you can see absolutely everything. The low beltline really helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26308415
>anything to look out for
rust
oil leaking/seeping. is an expensive fix. like, may as well swap the fucking engine. it will be burning oil at this point, nothing you can do to fix
rust
do a compression test
rust
>upgraydez
Chassis bracing. Cowl, frame rail, and butterfly braces. NAs were noodly when new, never mind after 30 years, and wifey will wonder why her kyuuuute new car rides like it's broken
if your summers get hot, the engine may need help keeping cool, particularly cylinder 4, which runs hotter than the rest because Mazda was retarded when putting the B engines into the Miata and couldn't be fucked to fix it over the NA/NB's lifetime. You might be able to get away with just radiator cowling to help the shitty airflow, otherwise it's time for better radiator and fan + cooling reroute
>hard top
Make sure to get a car with an OEM top already attached, otherwise you're in for a long and annoying hunt for a used top (good luck finding one under $2k), or spending $4.3k at cox mazda and waiting a year for a new one. They're big theft targets, too, and bolting them down properly makes them that much more annoying to take off. The non-OEM tops aren't great for street use and need additional finishing from a body shop or someone who knows their shit in order to fit well
>brakes
you don't really need to upgrade them unless you're doing trackdays
>backup camera
lol why
>fancy radio
install additional soundproofing if you go this route, otherwise there's no point
>heat and ac
the heater will probably work too well, AC will likely need some help, tho the hardtop will help keep the cold air in. Put heat shielding around the transmission tunnel between the tunnel and body, and maybe between carpet and body. Make sure the evap coil is clean, and if it still sucks, replace the condenser

I made the choice to keep them, because bigger brakes are not actually better for even the spirited street driving it sees. I don't experience any brake fade, and if you do on the street you've got issues. Maybe if it were engine swapped or turbo, but at it's current power level the stock brakes with good pads are absolutely plenty. The steering response, damping control, and lower inertia of having less unsprung weight is more important to me than having heavier eye candy calipers is. Either way, I'm thinking about painting them red, not lime green.

Starting work with pic rel pretty soon as a company driver, I’m just genuinely curious as to why people give company drivers, cents per mile pay, among other things, a bad rap. Besides the obvious (mile shortages, Pay issues, harsh scheduling) is there anything that really makes this specific position so much worse then, let’s say, being an owner operator, and having to pay out the ass for General DOT fuckery?

And, if this is really the worst position, what is recommended? Im young, inexperienced, and broke with very little to no expenses besides bills n food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306665
>>A serious trucker has entered the chat

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306734
Most company driver hate is memes, with some truth mixed in. In general, if you take pride in your work and learn the unspoken rules (like don't take your 30 in the fuel lane, and say no to flip flops) you will be ahead of 80% of the company drivers most are upset about.

Get your first year in, and immediately go find a company that pays better and doesn't hire students. You will almost always find your pay doubles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306827
How do most company positions feel about taking a girl along for extended period of time? I’m not talking about like, every once in a while, I mean more like 80 to 90% of my over the road time with girlfriend in passenger.

Should I just be doing local or dedicated (which I’m certain are very few with my experience and age) ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306869
Not him, but am familiar with the industry... Most companies allow a passenger to be brought along, but you should get their OK first though, for insurance purposes.

What sort of work you do is up to what you like. Some guys like highway, some guys like local. Highway is a good place to start though for the experience. I lasted about two years highway before the novelty wore off, and have only done various local work since then. I value home time more than I value an easy cruise down the highway. But I never regretted that time spent on the highway... I went to places that I would've never seen before, and got paid for it. Met some interesting characters along the way also.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306827
>>26306889

I appreciate it. Just hoping May treats us good enough for our lives to get started. Ill see if I can’t convince them to let me run local after a year or so, like last reply said I value home time a lot as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306979
You know it is what it is... It's not all bad really. The minute you're running for them means you're now in control of your own situation, being actively hired and trucking. If you don't smash up their shit on a regular basis, keep on trucking for them while enjoying new sights & smells, but start tossing out resumes to outfits like USPS if you want big pay with more home time. Or operate the concrete truck... I made good dollars operating the concrete mixer for a season. With experience under your belt, more options will open up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306979
I have a friend who started at May, functionally he said it was a good company, they keep you moving and treat you ok. The downside is the pay is low (for the industry) you will keep 6-700 a week.

But like i said above, get your year in, don't hit anything and you will double your salary when moving to a local/regional gig that requires experience. For instance, my brother runs fedex and is getting 1200/wk minimum guaranteed pay for fill in work.

posts.name: EF
posts.com:
>>26330363
Okay I’ll answer these even though I’m not ur google machine.
1:I go everywhere.
2:the trailer is a product of regulations. A closed tandem axle is allowed 34,000lbs a single axle is allowed 20,000lbs. Axles 10 feet apart are considered singles. So the trailer can scale 40,000lbs.
3:yes the tires scrub. For slow tight maneuvering I have a switch in the cab that dumps the air from the rear axle and the trailer rotates on the front axle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

A historical racing team named French Speed Connection has bought a JLOC Murcielago and a Taisan Viper (can't remember which year), they're restoring them and plan to race them in the Endurance Racing Legends championship taking place around Europe.
Unfortunately most JGTC/Super GT cars have either been dismantled or stored in some warehouse/yard and collecting dust and/or rust. Sometimes they're put up for sale to free up room, or auctioned off (recent examples include the Jim Gainer 360/430, #666 Bomex Avanzza Vemac, one of the 986 Boxsters that ran in GT300). Another interesting case is the Dijon Racing GT300 Corvette, it ended up being converted to a drift car by Daigo Saito

>>26264308
The Taisan F40 got auctioned off a couple of years ago and went for roughly $1 million.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Taisan F40's History

The JGTC (Japan GT Championship) started in 1994 and it laid the foundation for what was to become Japan's top racing category, Super GT.

One of the cars that received particular attention in Japan’s rich racing history was a Ferrari.
The Team Taisan Star Card F40.

At the time, the Italian GT Championship saw European dream cars such as the Porsche 964 Carrera RS and the Jaguar XJ220 line-up against each other. But when Yasutsune Chiba, the head of Team Taisan, came across an article in a magazine about how the F40 was dominating in Europe, he couldn’t help but dream of the F40 racing around Japanese circuits.

Chiba immediately bought an F40 and showed it off at the Fuji Speedway for the opening round of the JGTC season. The red body-coloured supercar was, of course, the talk of the race fans and drew a lot of attention. At the time, however, F40 racing parts were hard to come by and the car had to be driven in a virtually stock configuration. Despite its reputation, the F40 struggled to keep up with the other teams, who had built their cars with a wealth of experience.

However, for Chiba, running the F40 in a Japanese race series meant a lot to him and he refused to give up, improving the car race by race. This gradually paid off and they took pole position at the 4th round in Sugo. The team then brought in Oscar Larrauri, a former Italian GT Championship driver, to drive the car and team to victory.

In 1994, in the final race of the season, held at the Mine Circuit, the F40 made a spectacular start and took the lead, but the 962C, also from Team Taisan, was following closely. A fierce battle ensued between the two cars, but in the end the F40 took the chequered flag in 1st place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They ended the 1994 season on a strong note but the following season however, the F40 was unable to perform to its full potential due to the full scale support for Japanese works cars and the introduction of new regulations. As a result, the F40’s victory at Mine in 1994 was its first and last one in JGTC.
But the spectacle of this beautiful car speeding around a Japanese circuit, made possible by the enthusiasm of Team Taisan, has left a lasting impression on many race fans and became a legend that will live on forever.

https://bhauction.com/en/private-sales/1988-taisan-star-card-f40-jgtc-ferrari-f40-street-jgtc-ver-2

Depends on how heavy the extra kit to make the turbo work is. Superchargers usually end up being more efficient in terms of mpg while producing extra hp on account of the minimal extra kit required.
Turbos are hit and miss on the mpg count. They are typically used to squeeze more power out of a given engine block with less regards to fuel efficiency. (That’s on old tech of course, modern small-block engines built with efficiency and turbochargers from the beginning are built specifically for fuel efficiency but that’s a deliberate design rather than just lashing a turbo onto whatever engine you have laying around and hoping for fuel economy gains.)

Therefore, the crossplane rumble sound is only due to header design and nothing else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26326869
>that would cause the scavenging to be equivalent to a flatplane because of the routing
You're a complete moron.
Flatplanes ALWAYS alternate firing between Banks
L-R-L-R-L-R
Crossplanes do not and alternate depending on Firing Order (different for each manufacturer)
Crossplanes also do NOT have equal performance from EVERY cylinder, and must be TUNED to the lowest denominator
Flatplane offer equal performance from every cylinder
Therefor it's impossible to maintain the optimal exhaust Backpressure (to the correct Bank) even if you run convoluted unequal length Headers into Two or even One Collector.

>Therefore the sound of those engines will be indistinguishable from a flatplane with ideal scavenging assuming the entire rest of the engine and tuning stayed the same.
You hear that Bob's Muffler Shop? A Crossplane of the same displacement can be made to sound EXACTLY like a Flatplane.
You'll make a fortune turning Mustangs into Ferrari sounding.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26325229
>I still think those Koreans can't engineer properly as they have had decades of engineering R&D at their disposal and still can't muster ahead. Take for instance the Japanese, who have been making amazing machines since the 1950's.
The engineering philosophies are different. Korean auto companies will spend a lot on a new platform all at once, but don't like doing iterative improvements on existing stuff. If something is shit upon release, it doesn't get fixed until late into the platform, it's replaced with a new generation, or they're forced to. Japanese auto companies tend to amortize their development, preferring to do a lot of iterations over the same platform, which is why you'll have several different versions of a part on the same platform, depending on the year.

>It's when a car rolls in at the end of the 7 year warranty with no service history asking for warranty that it gets knocked back
A lack of a hand written note with dates and miles doesn't typically cause an engine to fail. It's weird what your customers must endure. Getting refused warranty service due to no in house documentation is the sort of bullshit I hear from those poor souls dumb enough to support your employer. Plus, lack of proof isn't the same as proof they didn't change the oil. Maybe you should look for proof they didn't change their oil.
>The sludge on the oilcap was huge
Do your engines direct an oil spray at the oil cap? I honestly don't know, your designers are shitty so they might. If they don't, it is only stray droplets that hit the cap. Not enough to keep the cap clean. If the seal around the pcv valve fails on a dusty road, the cap will have sludge. If the oil cap is loose at some point there will be sludge. Oil changes don't typically clean or replace the oil cap. That is an idiotic place to look for neglect. It's like you guys are just fishing for reasons to deny warranty coverage.
How did the rockers look? Did they have sludge? That would show neglect. Companies that sell cars not designed to fail can usually spring for a video inspection tool for their service team. I'm not surprised that you didn't mention using one.

You aren't honoring the warranty when you fish for reasons to deny before looking into the warranty claim. You are doing the opposite. Sadly, this is typical from the company that makes shitty cars which require a longer warranty in order to convince customers to buy their bottom tier crap.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281079
The more difficult part when i did the change on mine was getting the end links in. Getting the old bar out and new one in was fairly simple.
Si springs can be swapped over as well. 10mm drop, front spring rate is 7% higher (144.2lbs/in vs 126.8lbs/in) while the rears are 32% stiffer (208.8lbs/in vs 158.5lbs/in). Should help with reducing body roll/improving weight transfer, noticed with mine that it feels a bit wallowy when being pushed hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281787
Yeah that was my problem lol. Ended up unbolting the endlinks from the sway bar and bolting them to the control arm first, then the sway bar. I also thought of installing Si springs to keep her OEM+ but I want a modest drop, so I'm installing Eibach Pros next week. So far I've installed a Type R shift assembly, subframe brace, DC strut bar, this sway bar, and soon the springs. I'm out of ideas for what next. Maybe brakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281892
Brakes are a decent choice. DC5R calipers bolt straight on to the knuckle and go well with S2000 rotors, another option would be the Genesis Coupe Brembos paired with Rogue disks. DC5 Creations has a remachined TL Type S caliper that also directly bolts on (OEM ones use an M14 bolt rather than M12), need to use the TL-S rotors for that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281900
nice i'll look into those

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281900
>>26281950
btw are those plug and play or would I need to mod anything else? I've heard changing front calipers could throw off brake bias and/or mess with ABS

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281957
They should all be plug-n-play for the most part, bias will be more towards the front but the ABS should be able to figure it out. Just a warning though, the DC5R calipers will be the most expensive out of everything, over $1000 for a pair. Genesis coupe calipers are $700 from SlickFab, and the remachined TL-S ones are $515 at minimum if you're getting new calipers (will be less if you send in ones to be remachined)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26308203
Rough idle could be IACV like other anon said or other sensor issue. Every engine needs spark and air/fuel in the right amounts. IACV is most probable issue, if not look for issues with air and fuel like MAP sensor, O2 sensor, BPS, vacuum leak, etc. Try to get the fault code and rule out obvious stuff like cracked vacuum hoses or a clogged air filter. Other sensors like IAT, TPS, and ignition issues generally appear under load or at higher rpm and not idle.

no. No. NO. Do not spend more than you absolutely need to on your first car. Even if you’re rich.
best way to look at your first few cars is to treat them as if they’re disposable, definitely don’t buy new till you’ve got at least 5 years driving experience
remember they drop in value by about 15% per year so by the time it’s 3 years old it’s lost nearly half its value
>you will wreck your first car’s value (maybe your first few cars), either aesthetically with scratches/dents or a crash, so buy something as cheap as possible so that you’re not caught holding the bag: 5-15 years old is a good rule of thumb, depending on your budget

>keep in mind that you will need your second car sooner than you think (whether you wreck it, or you need something bigger, or whatever, it always happens suddenly and you’ll kick yourself if you can’t afford the car you need when you need it)
>start saving for your second car asap

Your options are the other fakes (Santa Cruz and Ridgeline) but they cost the same as real trucks

However these are all crewcab+square beds in length, the only way to really get a smaller truck is to get a half-ton ordered in single cab short bed. But those have really shitty 'value' once the dealer is scamming together the loan, especially after Stellantis jacked up the price on V6 Ram Classics. And you can't get something like a Ford's Powerboost hybrid in that size on an F150 because they only put it in crew cabs.

There are rumors that Stellantis might bring their own unibody RAM truck from abroad/mexico but they're always all talk. They've talked about reviving the Dakota for at least a decade now it feels.
If you really want small, you have to pay out the ass for a truck that survived 20 years of salt winters. You might be able to find an okay deal on a base single cab Tacoma between 2010~2015, if you don't mind the slow of a 4-cylinder.

Is the audi 4.2 reliable compared with most german powerplants?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281331
Why tho

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26284175
A lot of those older VAG engines are pretty solid, the main things to look out for on the 4.2 in particular are the intake manifold flaps (actuators tend to fail over time, making for less low-end torque) and the coil packs (which can be retrofitted for more modern ones with a simple adapter kit).
Chain-driven 4.2 40Vs are a different story (they're a nightmare), 4.2 FSIs still need the occasional major expensive service but they're less likely to slap you with it out of the blue like the chain-driven 40Vs do.

Reminder thats how the clio v6 was born.

An initial idea to drop in the turbocharged three-cylinder 12-valve engine from the Daihatsu Charade GTTi was scorched by problems mating up the electronics, but rather than scaling back his ambitions, Bruen went even wider, He began looking for a car with a wheelbase that would match the 92.3-inch (2345 mm) Twingo’s, and found one in the Ferrari 308 (92.1 inches, 2340 mm), which had a separate chassis, so theoretically could be fairly easily fused with the little Renault.


“The good thing was that the Ferrari came from a different [older] period, so the track was not that wide, whereas the Twingo, for its category was a very wide car,” remembers Breun.

But although he persuaded Renault to donate an unused Twingo shell and came close on more than one occasion to buying an accident-damaged 308 to get the project really rolling, Breun couldn’t quite pull the funds together to make it happen.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dxACf-txT48

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26301422
What do you mean?
The Libero typically only sends power to the rear axle, but the transmission allows locking the front axle to rear axle. When engaged, it's fully locked-- no speed difference allowed. So, you don't want to use it in normal grip circumstances-- you can hurt the transmission by turning on dry pavement with the front axle engaged. Putting a viscous coupling in the middle would allow the axles to move at different speed, so I could just keep the front axle engaged, drive around like normal, and the system will start locking if slippage occurs.

>>26280610
I have a few. Two in progress, one in the pipeline, and one as a pipe dream.

I have a 1989 Ramcharger body swapped onto a 1992 W250 Chassis I'm building as an off road rig. It's fully functional, pulls double duty as a farm truck and daily getting 20mpg despite 4.10 gearing and 37s. Excellent truck, 10/10, glad I went through with it. Just want to get some lockers and a roll cage so it's useable on more difficult trails.

I also have a 2012 Dodge Challenger R/T I'm getting ready to build into a full blown time attack car. Aero, suspension, extensive engine modification - more than I could reasonably list. I've had the plans for a decade, but the car has been my daily for most of that time, so going through with it hasn't been reasonable. It's my priority after I finish building my shop.

This Autumn, I plan on trailering my dad's derelict 1997 F-150 home to restore. It's just a base model long bed single cab, but it has memories attached to it. I want to rebuild the 4.9L with a little extra horsepower, but almost all the work will be in the aesthetics. Planning to do extensive bodywork and paint, two tone Pacific Green Metallic and Harvest Gold Metallic. I want to try to fit the next gen's King Ranch leather interior and also find a custom wheelmaker that can take the stock 17s and turn them into a nice 3 piece with a chrome lip and matching gold body. Really church it up into a show quality truck so I can give it back to the man who got me into cars.

Last one is a fantasy, but I really want to find a clapped 240Z and 340 Mopar swap it. I'd like to make it into a full N/A drag build, big tire with tubs and everything like a Pro Street car from the era. Even used CAD to mock up some 340Z emblems I wanted to custom make for it. It's a feasible build, but expensive due to how many S30s infested with rot and the prices hiking on clean ones, not to mention the cost of a 340 block and necessary fabrication to build it how I want.

Engines love cold weather, assuming they’re warmed up gradually and driven gently until then. If you routinely see below zero weather, blocking park of the grille/radiator will help getting up to and maintaining temp. Otherwise enjoy the low IATs and good cooling. I love pushing my 392 in the cold air, throttle response stays sharp, keeps the oil temp down and prevents the car from pulling timing as it warms up. Never realized how sluggish the car felt in 90 degree weather after my first winter driving it.

Alternatively, just swap the two speakers and if the sound swaps too, then it's a speaker issue, if the sound stays in the same place, then it's a wiring or even head unit issue.

>>26319019
The biggest problem with JDM fanboying is an outdated concept of reliability.

American cars took a reliability nosedive in the 70's and didn't come out of it until the late 80's or in some cases the early 90's. This was all due to emission shit that big V8s were burdened with while little shitter Japanese cars didn't need anything, so naturally the V8s suffered. Pretty much any 90's American sports car is as reliable if not more reliable than an equally powerful Japanese car. Only some shitter Corolla might edge out a Mustang, for example, but that's not apples to apples by a long shot.

All of the high end JDM cars are ticking time bombs unless you really pull out all the stops and spend 10's of thousands on mods. Even for handling the Japanese flagships were often boats full of unnecessary bullshit so handling is nothing special, either. The American cars also tend to have pretty comfy roomy engine bays vs. god awfully tight JDM engine bays on everything but front engine 4 cylinders. I can't believe how comparatively easy it is to get around a C5 or New Edge Mustang engine bay compared to most JDM cars.

I'm over it, personally. I only liked Japanese cars because everyone told me they were reliable and American cars weren't, but I'm quickly learning that all of that was outdated 30 years ago and they're fine if you remotely maintain them. Any real world reliability differences come down more to negligent owners that bought the American car because it was the cheapest in its class and never spent a penny on maintenance and ragged the hell out of it while some Corolla buyer went to every maintenance interval and never took it past 2/3 of the rev range.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26319019
The biggest blind spot I see consistently is the effect of regulations and taxes on vehicle design. People assume that a Japanese (or Euro) sports car that competes with an American car should basically have the same performance and qualities, as they are competitors. In reality, Japanese and Euro brands CAN'T compete with American sports cars because they are born from an entirely different legal world. Japs and Euros face stiff taxes on displacement and in some cases outright bans due to emissions bullshit. This means you either literally CAN'T make a V8 car or if you do it has to be so expensive due to taxes/fees that it is a luxury car by default. Consider a Mustang GT which in Netherlands costs something like $80k... if you're going to spend $80k on a car most people would rather pay $100k and have a non-dogshit interior, whereas adding that additional $20k in price to an American mustang (going from $40k to $60k) is a much different proposition. However, the other thing people don't realize is that comparing 0-60 times and such as if faster always means better is the definition of bench racing. In the real world these things aren't that important and they're just one part of the entire sports car experience.

The truth of the matter is that they were hit or miss in terms of potential. The third gen RX-7 was more or less middle of the pack in terms of stock performance, but those cars can be absurdly fast even by modern standards if you do the right things to them. The fourth gen Supra wasn't a particularly great car so much as it was an okay car that came with a remarkably bulletproof motor. Subarus as you point out are basically rebuilds waiting to happen the moment you do anything to the motor but are otherwise good for what they are.

The cars that more or less did live up to the hype then and now were some 90s Hondas and DSMs, but even then, we were always in the shadow of higher trims/better cars that were released outside of the US. Now that we can import them it feels like a dream come true for those who remember owning an Eclipse but really wanting an Evo IV. Personally, I'm a fan of getting more car than what I paid for and not less, which is why a lot of those cars have fallen off of my radar. Miatas, MR2s, etc. can still be found for a decent price in some parts of the US, but otherwise, these cars have priced themselves out of relevancy for anyone who isn't hard parking them.

>>26319019
JDM cars are the best cars you could get for all-around "fun", because they are lightweight and handle well but still can make good power. They were built on the premise that a car should handle great and not be overweight whereas a lot of western sports/performance cars care about numbers more than how it feels to drive.

Nowadays all the rage is "muh horsepower!!", all anyone cares about is getting 1000's of horsepower. "Bruh your car aint making 750 horsepower bruh? lmao lame stupid gay haha!"

I've enjoyed driving 400 horsepower naturally aspirated 370z's and 350 horsepower boosted BRZ's more than driving 800 horsepower mustangs/corvettes. Would I really want a car that needs drag radials to put power to pavement from a stop and can't be pushed hard for more than a second without flying past the speed limit (orb reaking something) over a car that has more practical and thoroughly enjoyable power?

>But why JDM? BMW/Ford/etc makes 6 and 4-cyl cars!

Because ANY 4-banger/V6 car made by a company that has a V8 trim to the same car is going to be shit. You're getting the extra weight and the "Haha it's not a v8 model!" factor for a dirt cheap economy engine that isn't nearly as good as a purpose built top-trim V6/I6 in a JDM car. Sure, you can make a V6 camaro or a eco boost Mustang fast, but if you wanted to go fast in one of them why not just get the V8 trim? There is no V8 trim to a Z or a Supra or etc.

>>26325625
>Why does the Celica make car guys seethe so much?
nothing really wrong with it as a platform- especially the limited edition TRD ones with a more powerful engine and a manual transmission. It was made during a time Toyota was at a weird point where they were trying to merge the motorsport tech they've gained from the 1990's with modern 2000's consumerist comfortable machines. People dislike this version of Celica in particular because it detracted so much from the previous Celicas it gained the name from. The previous Celicas were AWD or RWD platforms and have extensive motorsport heritage.

This modern iteration on the other hand, was an ode to early-2000's Fast Furious influence. They were more trying to gain the Honda Civic audience but failed to do so properly. When you modify this generation of Celica, you can have a decent peppy, track machine of sort. Many aftermarket parts available to tune it to your liking. But there were just so many better Japanese platforms out there and not to mention the European scene at the time as well as American machines of the early-2000's. (Think Pontiac G8 and Mustang GT). Thankfully Toyota today are going back to their roots and manufacturing more sporty machines again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6xFo_oHFF48

if it's killing the battery in just one night it's something that's pulling a ton of current
first tool you want is an amp clamp aka hall effect sensor to measure the actual parasitic draw rate and prove that is what is happening
it will be massive if you are in fact discharging a battery that quickly
at that rate your battery will be fucked very quickly, you should never deep cycle a generic SLA battery, and if you keep driving it your alternator will be fucked too

yes there are pro tools for this, they are not cheap
they may save some effort/time but not money

posts.name: Anonymous

they require using your multimeter as part of the circuit as it measures how much current flows through your meter, an amp-clamp measures the current through a cable from the outside leaving the circuit intact and thus it can also measure much bigger loads. you cant run your starter through a regular multimeter but you can measure such several-100A with a clamp.
its the tool all pro's use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26327930
Why would OP be cranking the engine while trying to track a current draw with the key off? Are you retarded or something?

OP, just remove the negative lead from the battery, hold it against the neg terminal on the battery (completing the circuit) and put one multimeter lead on the negative terminal and the other on the negative battery cable, then separate the battery cable and the terminal so now the only thing completing the circuit is your multimeter. It should read less than 250 miliamps, if it's higher than that you've got a problem and you can start pulling fuses to find out where it is. DONT key the car on and DONT try and start it like the dumbfuck above is trying to tell you.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26327931
>Do you need high end speakers as well? Is putting in nice new speakers without getting a new head unit really that bad
most stock head units for older vehicles won't be able to take advantage of the extra power that (decent) aftermarket speakers can offer. I don't know if this is still the case with late model cars. Audio tech has come a long way from the 80s and 90s, today's aftermarket stock replacement speakers would probably have been yesterday's top of the line premium offerings.
if your factory speakers are shot and you want to keep the stock head unit, look for ones that match your head unit's impedance otherwise they will sound distorted at best, or overheat the head unit at worst when you try to crank the volume up. And make sure the sensitivity is as high as possible. 88 dB is typically acceptable if you just want something that works with your stock head unit, but higher is always better, especially if the factory speakers already had a high sensitivity (unlikely for older cars).

I put a Battery Tender on my Jeep while it's garaged for the winter.
I don't disconnect the battery from the car, and it doesn't harm anything to leave it connected while on the trickle charger. It's an old car though, and the radio is the only electronic thing on it (no ECU or anything), but I can't imagine it would be a problem to keep the battery connected, because the charger should manage the voltage.
As long as you have a good quality charger, it should be fine.

The stutter there kind of sounds like a weak battery. Does it just keep cranking like that without starting? Or does it stop cranking like that stutter? Have you measured the battery voltage or attached a charger?

If it'll keep cranking like that but never fire, the engine has compression I can hear so you either lack spark or fuel. Spark you can check by pulled a spark plug and using an insulated tool to hold it against something metal while you crank to see if you see spark. Fuel you can attach a pressure gauge or unhook the fuel line and put it in a jar to see if it fills while cranking. Based on what's missing you can narrow down the problem.

>>26315364
Cut off the burnt tape, wrap it in new harness tape, and figure out some kind of heatshield. Metal conducts heat very well, so you need an air gap between the heat shield, simply wrapping it in metal tape won't do much. Maybe a small piece of metal with air on either side.

Possibly a small piece of sound deadening wrapped around with some zip ties could work, just monitor for melting.

Can that egr pipe be bent away a bit? even like a half inch could make a big difference. Make your fix, warm up your engine thoroughly, and use a IR heat thermometer to see if it's getting too hot.

>>26321011
The UK has a well established and thriving car scene.
As an immigrant, you'll be shafted by insurance for a few years, but it will quickly go down as your period of residency increases. Saying that, if you're willing to ship vehicles over (shipping alone will be a few thousand dollars per car).
We have inspections in the UK, but as long as your car isn't rusted to shit, and you're not doing things like removing brake lights, it's one of the easier inspections in Western Europe to pass.
I know lots of people who modify their cars, my dad has a kit car, I can't think of anything you can't do. I recently found out about a company who makes kits that allow you to drop a Jaguar V6 in to a MX-5 NB.
Like in Finland, if you're heavily modifying your car you may need to re-register it but it's not a massive problem. If you're really thinking outside the box, I'm sure you can find plenty of help online or with local car clubs with someone who can offer some guidance.

>>26321193
No. Car registration and taxation is different in each country. Your car must be registered in the place where you are resident for at least 185 days of the year so you can't register your car in Finland and move to Italy (in theory)
In practice in pre-Brexit UK, Eastern European immigrants would bring their cars over and not register them and I don't think the police really gave a shit. There's been an E46 BMW with Bulgarian number plates near where I work for nearly eight years now.
Here in the UK all standard insurance policies I've had post-Brexit have covered me for 90 days of driving a year in the EU, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, and Andorra. I've even looked at cover for driving in Turkey for a few weeks and it was very reasonably priced.
If you really wanted, you could drive from the UK to Mongolia and all you really need is visas, insurance, and proof of ownership.
https://www.theadventurists.com/guides/mongol-rally/

I have seen a diagram of a slightly different looking canister which shows that the small diameter vacuum hose controls a valve which allows vapor to be sucked through the larger hose out of the canister into the TB. If the first explanation is correct, i don't understand why, when you drive the car immediately after starting it (before the 02 sensors are heated up enough for the fuel system to be in closed loop control mode), the car drives perfectly fine, when by this explanation it should be getting extra fuel that is unaccounted for from the evap canister when vacuum opens that valve. I think i may be not fully understanding how the car manages fuel trim? Is it not that it uses data from the car's intake sensors until the 02 sensors are heated, and then after that switches to having fuel trim be controlled solely by upstream 02 sensor feedback?

posts.com:
>>26321889
Engines with higher compression require higher octane fuel in order to prevent engine knock, which is when the fuel combusts too early due to being compressed.
Modern engines that "require" premium gas usually have a mode that allows them to run with lower octane gas while simply making less power. This is probably why people assume that premium fuel contains more energy than regular, which is false.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26321123
If the lights on the passenger sill aren't coming on, you'd want to check the harness that's either in the door, or under the A-pillar. I bet you have a short somewhere that's causing the issue.

I'd start at the fuse boxes and check connections there. If you have a multimeter you could check the voltages from the fuse box to the harness. If somebody did any wiring in the interior, they could have pinched a wire. I pinched a wire rigging up a dash cam in my Lesback and I had similar weird gremlins pop up until I figured it out.

I have an S550, but iirc there's a conduit from the door harness into the A-pillar. There's a harness in the door for the side mirrors that the puddle lights would go through and there's a harness behind the glove box for the sill light. they would both join there behind the glove box then head over to the fuse box in the interior iirc. id check along that path.

I fuckin hate electrical so here's what I do:
draw it out
work backwards to the power source
write down your knowns as you know them: have power at mirrors, don't have power to p side sill, x wire not grounded, too much too little voltage on y wire, etc

its a bitch, I fuckin hate electrical and id rather pay somebody but if I were you, that's where id start

FYI Generally to approximately double horse power on any given engine you'd need a Turbo charger to put out 14-15 psi, and most stock engines can't take that. Basic turbocharger systems that put out 5-6 psi are usually in the 5000$ range or more.

Superchargers put out less peak PSI, and have more parasitic losses but are cheaper than turbo systems usually.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26331277
>explain, are you talking about the pistons, valves, etc because i would assume the actual blocks of the engine itself would be fine, its just solid steel/aluminium

Anything that's the weakest point in the engine, including the block. Blocks are not some infallible unbreakable piece of metal, they can fail to over pressure or twisting forces applied to them. Some designs are more susceptible to damage with any modifications, and in general pure aluminum blocks without sleeving are weaker than iron blocks, and open deck blocks tend to be weaker than closed deck blocks.

Unless you live in some frozen hellscape you can look up the capacity of your system, drain out about half of that, and then add antifreeze until it's full again. If you filled it with tap water or hose water instead of distilled water, though, you should drain it anyway. If you do live in a frozen hellscape then you probably should drain it fully to make sure you get the most correct amount of antifreeze in there when you refill.
